Content.Question:
car

1279 W. Page, Three Early Assize Rolls Northumberland “Thom. Kerhand.”

1327 J. Stuart, Exchequer Rolls Scotl. “Henrico dicto kerhand.”

1440 Unknown, Awntyrs Arthure “With a caste of þe care, in kautelle he strykes.”

1499 Unknown, Wisdom of Solomon “The visdome of the wisman is in his rycht hand and the foly of the ful in his kere hand.”

1550 Unknown, Complaynt Scotl. “He resauit the vryting in his kar hand.”

1597 J. Skene, De Verborum Significatione “Vpon the ker and wrang side, was placed the thrid Idole, Frigga.”

1600 D. Masson, Reg. Privy Council Scotl. “mutilat him in the ker hand of tua fingeris.”

1721 J. Kelly, Compl. Coll. Scotish Prov. “You'll go the Car Gate yet.”

1743 Unknown, Scots Mag. “It has a meikle maun blue pouch hingin' at the carr side o'd, fou o' mullens and chucky-stanes.”

1787 F. Grose, Provinc. Gloss. “Car-hand, the left hand.”

1825 J. Jamieson, Etymol. Dict. Sc. Lang. “If you meet a car-handit, i.e. a left-handed person, or one who has flat soles.”

1895 ‘G. Setoun’, Sunshine & Haar “Pillan's compliments..is a' car-pawed.”

1928 J. Carruthers, Man Beset “He's aye glaikin' wi' weemen, but naebody can say he's ker-handit wi' a coo.”

1988 W. A. D. Riach, Galloway Gloss. “Car, left-handed.”

2005 M. Rodger, Borth'ick Waitter “On yer ker haund, is ee gan doon the hill end yonner, is ae wheen auld treis up on the brae face.”
Content.Answer:
car - Left, esp. in car-hand, car-handed; (also) left-handed. Sometimes with implication of awkwardness or wrongness (cf. sinister, adj.). Also occasionally (e.g. in quot. 1440) as n.: †the left hand (obsolete).
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1070 Unknown, Anglo-Saxon Chron. “Eadwerd cing scylode ix scypa of male.”

1122 Unknown, Anglo-Saxon Chron. “Se cyng sealde his land swa deore to male, swa heo deorost mihte.”

1175 Unknown, Ormulum “Forrþi badd hemm sannt iohan..sammnenn laȝhelike. & rihht Þe kingess rihhte male.”

1199 Unknown, MS Trin. Cambr. “And giet ne wile þe louerd ben paid mid his rihcte mol.”

1299 Unknown, Vision St. Paul “Of men hoe taken hounriȝt mol.”

1396 Unknown, Sc. Antiquary “The forsayd Scher Jone sal haf the malys of Ouchtyrtyre.”

1399 Unknown, Cursor Mundi “I gif him wonynge stede to wale for euermare, wiþ-outen male.”

1485 G. Hay, Bk. Law of Armys “The cristin men, yat ar duelland jn the mistrowand menis housis vndermalis, suld be lele to thair malaris, and obeisand.”

1499 R. Henryson, Fables: Wolf & Lamb “Scantlie may he purches by his maill To leue vpon dry breid.”

1550 Unknown, Complaynt Scotl. “The malis and fermis of the grond..is hychtit to sic ane price.”

1622 Unknown, Linlithgow Burgh Rec. “Na flescheris to ber any mal of the standes.”

1746 Unknown, Act 20 Geo. II “Recovering and uplifting from the vassals..the mails and duties or rents and profits thereof.”

1767 J. Erskine, Inst. Law Scotl. “The arrears of rent, or, in our law-style, of mails and duties, prescribe, if.”

1824 W. Scott, Redgauntlet “The rental-book..bore evidence against the Goodman of Primrose-Knowe, as behind the hand with his mails and duties.”

1861 G. Ross, W. Bell's Dict. Law Scotl. “Maills and Duties are the rents of an estate, whether in money or grain; hence, an action for the rents of an estate..is termed an action of maills and duties.”

1900 S. R. Crockett, Little Anna Mark “He carried a great sum about with him, being the rents and mails of all his New Milns property.”

1969 J. Fowles, French Lieutenant's Woman “If one cherished one's crops or one's daughter's virginity one paid mail to the neighbourhood chieftains.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Payment, tax, tribute, rent. In O.E. also: †agreement, deal (obsolete). mails and duties: the rents of an estate. Cf. blackmail, n.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1228 N. S. B. Gras, Early Eng. Customs Syst. “i fraiello de vaddo, i poke de alum, i pak mailede.”

1570 J. Foxe, Actes & Monumentes “It was matted about with mattes and mayled in littell bundels about ij. foote long.”

1588 R. Parke, Hist. Kingdome of China “was mailed and sealed and so sent vnto the viceroy of Aucheo.”

1594 W. Shakespeare, Henry VI, Pt. 2 “Thus with burning Tapor in my hand, Malde vp in shame with papers on my backe.”

1598 M. Drayton, Englands Heroicall Epist. “How could it be, those that were wont to stand, To see my pompe..Should after see mee mayld vp in a sheet, Do shamefull penance.”

1601 J. Weever, Mirror of Martyrs “Then ledde I warre mailde vp in sheetes of brasse.”

1619 Unknown, Let. fr. Factors at Surat to E.I.C. “To whom wee have delivered a box sealed, maled, and covered.”

1653 T. Fowler, Hist. Corpus Christi Coll. “A basket mal'd up with Cords.”

1657 J. Trapp, Comm. Ezra “Who..do miserably mail themselves in the filthiness of leudnesse.”

1660 F. Brooke, World Surveyed “Three hundred Elephants follow richly mail'd with Sea-wolf skins.”

1694 W. Burnaby, Satyr “He run into the House, leaving behind him an Embroider'd Mantle, mail'd to one of the Saddles.”
Content.Answer:
mail - transitive. To tie or wrap up (goods, a parcel, etc.); to envelop. Also figurative and with up. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1575 G. Turberville, Bk. Faulconrie “Mayle your Hawke fast.”

1619 E. Bert, Approved Treat. Hawkes “I did male them vp in a handkercher... I would not male vp the tops of her flying feathers.”

1625 J. Fletcher, Maid in Mill “If you had..handled her as men do unmand Hawks, Cast her, and malde her up in good clean linnen.”

1883 J. E. Harting, Gloss. “To mail a hawk, i.e. to wrap her up in a handkerchief..either to tame her,..or to keep her quiet during an operation.”

1967 M. Woodford, Man. Falconry “To mail a hawk, i.e. to wrap her up in a sock, or handkerchief.”
Content.Answer: mail - transitive. Falconry. To wrap up (a hawk) in a cloth, etc., to promote tameness or to ensure passivity during an operation. Also with up. Now rare.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1275 Laȝamon, Brut “Ich þe wulle bi-tache a male riche.”

1300 Unknown, Havelok “A man that bore..gold up-on hijs bac, In a male with or blac.”

1330 Unknown, Bevis of Hampton “Inouȝ a leide him be-fore, Bred and flesc out of is male.”

1395 G. Chaucer, Canon's Yeoman's Tale “A male tweyfolde on his croper lay.”

1474 J. Paston, Paston Lett. & Papers “I prey yow that Pytt may trusse in a male..my tawny gowne.”

1552 Unknown, Act 5 & 6 Edw. VI “Such as make Males, Bougets, Leather Pots,..or any other Wares of Leather.”

1567 R. Pitcairn, Criminal Trials Scotl. “To tak up ane carriage of twa maills, the ane ane tronk, and the vthir ane ane leddirin mail.”

1599 T. Deloney, Thomas of Reading “They..tooke away the mans apparell, as also his money, in his male or capcase.”

1609 Unknown, Bible (Douay) “The bread is spent in our males.”

1653 Unknown, Edinb. Test. “Tua lairge maills with hatt caisis.”

1670 C. Cotton, Hist. Life Duke of Espernon “His Jewels..were lock'd up in a little iron Chest, and carried in a Male.”

1706 Unknown, Phillips's New World of Words “Mail,..also a kind of Port-mantle, Sack or Trunk to travel with.”

1820 W. Scott, Abbot “They charged me with bearing letters for the Queen, and searched my mail.”

1893 R. L. Stevenson, Catriona “He..emptied out his mails upon the floor that I might have a change of clothes.”

1923 J. Buchan, Midwinter “Awa in wi' ye and get warm, and I'll bring your mails.”
Content.Answer: mail - A bag, pack, or wallet; a travelling bag, a portmanteau. In later use Scottish and U.S. in plural: baggage. †Also figurative.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1299 Unknown, Prov. Hendyng “Þe glotoun, þer he fint goed ale, He doþ so muchel in his male.”

1324 Unknown, Gen. & Exod. “Quhu lucifer, ðat deuel Dwale..held hem sperd in helles male.”

1390 G. Chaucer, Parson's Tale “Vnbokele and shewe vs what is in thy male.”

1438 J. Lydgate, Fall of Princes “Yif ye shal telle your owne tale..Ye will vnclose but a litil male, Shewe of your vices but a smal parcel.”

1449 J. Mirk, Instr. Parish Priests “Art þow I-wonet to go to þe ale To fulle þere thy fowle male?”

1475 J. Lydgate, Order of Fools “Tabourerys..Plese more this daies whan stuffed in ther male.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Something likened to a bag; esp. the stomach or belly. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
the mail wries

1450 J. Capgrave, Life St. Katherine “Hough acordeth this tale? Al a wrong, me thenketh, wriheth the male.”

1475 Unknown, Advice to Lovers “The male so wryes That no kunnyng may prevayl..Ayens a wommans wytt.”

1522 J. Skelton, Why come ye nat to Courte “The countrynge at Cales Wrang vs on the males.”

1528 J. Skelton, Phyllyp Sparowe “Though his father were a kyng Yet there was a thyng That made tha male to wryng.”

1528 J. Skelton, Colyn Cloute “And so they blere your eye Howe the male dothe wryte.”
Content.Answer:
the mail wries - figurative. In phrases the mail wries (also wrings): fortune turns, things turn out (usually badly); to wring (a person) on the mails: to cause trouble to. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1503 R. Arnold, Chron. “Wulle is bought by the sacke by the tod, by the stone and by the mayle.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A bag as a measure of quantity. Obsolete. rare.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1654 Unknown, Ord. Office Postage Lett. “To have in readiness one good Horse or Mare to receive and carry the Male of Letters... That no other person (besides the Post that carrieth the Male) be suffered to ride Post with the Male.”

1684 Unknown, London Gaz. “Our Pacquet-Boats put to Sea yesterday with the Mails for Calais.”

1692 N. Luttrell, Diary “Yesterday a Flanders mail of an old date, confirms the several repulses of the enemy.”

1711 Unknown, Boston News-let. “The Mayle of Letters from Boston on Saturday next per the Post.”

1746 T. Smollett, Reproof “With all the horrors of prophetic dread That rack his bosom while the mail is read.”

1767 G. Colman, Eng. Merchant “I collect the articles of news from the other papers..translate the mails, write occasional letters.”

1776 C. Carroll, Jrnl. “Dr. Franklin found in the Canada mail, which he opened, a letter for General Schuyler.”

1782 W. Cowper, Expostulation “Now think,..If the new mail thy merchants now receive, Or expectation of the next, give leave.”

1792 Unknown, Stat. U.S. “That if any person..shall rob any carrier of the mail..of such mail, or if any person shall rob the mail, in which letters are sent to be conveyed by post..or shall steal such mail.”

1794 Unknown, Stat. U.S. “And the letters so received shall be formed into a mail, sealed up, and directed to the postmaster of the port.”

1838 Unknown, Act 1 & 2 Victoria “The Mails or Post Letter Bags so to be carried..by Railways.”

1852 N. Hawthorne, Jrnl. “John's boat, (the regular passenger-boat) is now coming in, and probably brings the mail.”

1873 W. Black, Princess of Thule “Everything will be as right as the mail.”

1873 J. H. Beadle, Undeveloped West “I think this office gives us three times as much mail as that at Salt Lake.”

1883 Unknown, Whitaker's Almanack “India.—Mails made up every Friday evening at the rate of 5d. per ½ oz.”

1893 Unknown, Daily News “Little incidents of camp life in the East, as the arrival and distribution of a mail of letters.”

1913 Unknown, U.S. Official Postal Guide “The postage on fourth-class mail may be prepaid by..ordinary postage stamps.”

1941 Unknown, Men Only “Forwarding mail is another job that usually falls to the Mess Secretary.”

1966 ‘J. Hackston’, Father clears Out “When Mother asked him if he were really going to post the letter.., he swore that this one was going to the mail.”

1966 ‘J. Hackston’, Father clears Out “The mail closes tomorrow.”
Content.Answer: mail - A bag or packet of letters or dispatches for conveyance by post (more fully †mail of letters). In later use chiefly: the postal matter (or a quantity of letters, packages, etc.) conveyed in this manner; all that is conveyed by post on one occasion. With definite article or without article. Also (chiefly in North American usage) in plural, and (chiefly South Asian) with indefinite article.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1654 Unknown, Ord. Office Postage Lett. “The said John Manley..shall..safely and faithfully carry all..Letters and Dispatches..and that by the Common, Ordinary Male or other speedy and safe passage.”

1692 N. Luttrell, Diary “One letter by the last mail sayes, the king intended to fight the enemy Satturday 7 night last.”

1720 Unknown, London Gaz. “The Bristol Mail was robbed.”

1778 A. Adams, “Four or five sheets of paper, written to you by the last mail, were destroyed when the vessel was taken.”

1794 S. T. Coleridge, Lett. “I..sent them off by the mail directed to Mrs. Southey.”

1831 Unknown, Parl. Papers “When it is permitted in England for the mails to take parcels on the road.”

1842 Ld. Tennyson, Walking to Mail “I fear That we shall miss the mail.”

1856 T. De Quincey, Confessions Eng. Opium-eater “The mails were..made so strong as to be the heaviest of all carriages.”

1861 Unknown, Amer. Agriculturist “Useful information in regard to all matters connected with the Mails, Post Offices, etc.”

1862 Unknown, Building News “Locomotives and Tenders. 494 First Class Mails.”

1880 Unknown, Printing Trades Jrnl. “Tender and brittle, and hardly bears its journey through the mail.”

1888 Unknown, Amer. Humorist “Why didn't he send his poem by mail?”

1891 Unknown, 37th Rept. Postm.-General “Sixty-four additional direct Parcel Mails between London and other places have been established in the year.”

1900 Unknown, Post Office Guide “When intended for despatch by a particular mail they should..be presented for registration half an hour before the closing of the letter-box for that mail.”

1912 Unknown, Railroad Man's Mag. “The manifest freight Pulled out on the stem behind the mail.”

1938 Unknown, Time “The U.S. Circuit Court of appeals ruled that physicians might send contraceptives by mail.”

1944 H. L. Mencken, Diary “The Postoffice smellers are vigilant for violations of the federal act forbidding the use of the mails to promote them.”

1992 Unknown, Sun (Baltimore) “PC makers that sell through the mail via toll-free numbers.”

1994 Unknown, Guardian “The Royal Mail has turned its die-printing on its side to produce a horizontal ordinary first-class stamp.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A person, vehicle, or train that carries the mail or postal matter; often short for mail coach, train, van, etc. Also (chiefly North American and Australian): the system of conveyance and delivery of letters, etc., by post (also in plural); the official organization responsible for this activity in a particular country; the post.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1789 Unknown, “The Evening Mail.”

1823 Unknown, “Waterford Daily Mail.”

1896 Unknown, “The daily mail.”

1896 D. Lloyd George, Family Lett. “There are excellent reports in the Mail & S.W. Daily News of Saturday's meeting at Barry.”

1922 J. Joyce, Ulysses “Look here Martin, John Wyse Nolan said, overtaking them at the Mail office.”

1975 Unknown, Times “The tremendous financial support that the Daily Mail has received..from its readers for its Vietnam Orphans Fund.”

1990 Unknown, Guardian “Baz Babigoyne of the Mail says he was called a ‘smear-agent of the Right’.”
Content.Answer: mail - Used in the titles of newspapers.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1843 M. C. Field, “He walks as if he had the missing mail in his pocket and an extra to issue immediately.”

1890 T. L. James, Railways Amer. “That official was opening his mail.”

1901 Unknown, Harper's Mag. “Stormfield in his mail that day..found a despatch: ‘Unexpectedly called home’.”

1953 Unknown, Manch. Guardian Weekly “Mr. Lattimore..had his personal mail forwarded to the White House.”

1992 Unknown, Daily Express “Diana was so paranoid about Palace intrusion, she..shredded all her mail.”
Content.Answer: mail - Originally U.S. The letters, packages, etc., delivered to or intended for one address or individual.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1970 Unknown, Proc. IEEE “Electronic typer: Soft copy..Basic business and home unit for mail, computer time sharing, and transaction exchange.”
Content.Answer: mail - Computing. = electronic mail, n. 1. rare.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1972 A. K. Bhushan, Request for Comments “The use of would allow a network user to send mail to other users who do not have NIC identification but whose is known.”

1983 Unknown, Proc. AFIPS Conf. “Similar communications systems will evolve for electronic mail. Employees will have IDs on their company's internal mail system as well as on at least one public system.”

1986 D. Deutsch, “Some systems also inform their users about new mail during a session.”

1992 Unknown, PC World “The principle motivation is mail's potential role as the foundation for controlling the next generation of PC software—‘mail enabled’ applications.”

1993 Unknown, UNIX Rev. “SLIP allows network services that use TCP/IP—mail, netnews, X Windows—to run over a serial line.”

1993 Unknown, Wired “What are the risks of running a large mailing list?.. The biggest problem is the barf mail—fielding ten new pieces of rejected mail every day.”

1998 Unknown, Industry Standard “Server agents..might be set to watch for a certain frequency of mail transmission, setting off an alert if an unusually high number of messages goes out or if there is a steady stream of mail over a period of time from one account.”
Content.Answer: mail - Computing. = electronic mail, n. 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1975 Unknown, Bulletin (Sydney) “His mail was that if I didn't weigh in soon I'd be gathered for sure.”

1983 Unknown, Sun-Herald (Sydney) “The mail is the Minister for Sport, Mike Cleary, is wary of new betting introductions following footie flop.”

1984 Unknown, Age (Melbourne) “I had never heard of the horse before. I didn't receive any special ‘mail’ on it, but I've gone to races all my life—money speaks all languages.”
Content.Answer: mail - Australian slang. Information, rumour, news; esp. a (racing) tip.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1330 Unknown, Guy of Warwick “Of mailes was nouȝt his hauberk; It was al of anoþer werk.”

1380 Unknown, Sir Ferumbras “Of ys auantaile, wyþ þat stroke a carf wel many a maylle.”

1450 Unknown, Libeaus Desconus “An hawberk bryȝt, Þat rychely was a-dyȝt Wyth mayles þykke and smale.”

1475 Unknown, Awntyrs Arthure “Syxti maylis and moe The squrd squappes in toe.”

1521 G. Douglas, Aeneid “As golden mailȝeis hir scalis glitterand brycht.”

1549 M. Coverdale, Paraphr. Newe Test. “For the breste plate, put on innocencie and righteousnes, to kepe the inward partes of your mynd safe and sure with the mayles of vertue and godlines.”

1598 A. M., Frenche Chirurg. “To drawe out any..Mayles which mighte remayne stitckinge in the Wounde.”

1611 R. Cotgrave, Dict. French & Eng. Tongues “Annelet, a mayle, or a ring of mayle.”

1706 Unknown, Phillips's New World of Words “Mail, a little Iron-ring for Armour.”

1846 F. W. Fairholt, Costume in Eng. “The mailles or rings of the hauberk appear,..sewn down..on a sort of gambeson.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Any of the metal rings (or plates) of which mail-armour is composed; also figurative. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1330 Unknown, King of Tars “Þai schul ben alle redi diȝt Wiþ helme & hauberk of meile.”

1380 Unknown, Sir Ferumbras “Olyuer..for-hewþ hem plate & maille.”

1395 G. Chaucer, Clerk's Tale “Thogh thyn housbond armed be in maille.”

1424 G. Chaucer, Troilus & Criseyde “Achilles, thorugh the maille And thorugh the body, gan hym for to ryve.”

1450 Unknown, Libeaus Desconus “Hys fomen wer well boun To perce hys acketoun, Gypell, mal and plate.”

1465 M. Paston, Paston Lett. & Papers “A standerd of mayle.”

1521 G. Douglas, Aeneid “Abowt his schuldris assais his hawbryk fyne, Of burnist maill.”

1540 Unknown, Gest Historiale Destr. Troy “Sho was bare of hir breast to þe bright mayll.”

1552 J. H. Burton, Reg. Privy Council Scotl. “A jack of plett, steilbonet, splent slevis, of mailyie or plait.”

1600 J. Pory, Geogr. Hist. Afr. “Their armour..certaine shirts of male verie long and streight.”

1667 J. Milton, Paradise Lost “Mangl'd with gastly wounds through Plate and Maile.”

1748 J. Thomson, Castle of Indolence “Yclad in steel, and bright with burnish'd mail.”

1789 R. Hole, Arthur “No temper'd mail resists Fiacha's might.”

1810 T. Campbell, O'Connor's Child “Every bosom shook Beneath it's iron mail.”

1838 E. Bulwer-Lytton, Leila “The king..was..armed cap-à-pie in mail.”

1877 W. Morris, Sigurd “Through the glimmering thicket the linked mail rang out.”

1904 J. Parkinson, Lays Love & War “What ho! my spear, My mail, and helm, and gleaming tahali.”

1940 T. H. White, Ill-made Knight “The sentries made smart about-turns, their mail ringing on the stone floor.”

1984 G. McCaughrean, Canterbury Tales “Knights caparisoned in mail, heraldic surcoats, and plumes fit for birds-of-paradise.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Armour composed of interlaced rings or chain-work or of overlapping plates fastened upon a groundwork. coat of mail: see coat, n. 5.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1440 Unknown, Liber de Diversis Med. “An oþer for þe maile in þe eghen.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “Which eyesalve they say, serveth also for the mailles or spots..in the eyes.”

1847 J. O. Halliwell, Dict. Archaic & Provinc. Words “Mail, a defect in vision. Devon.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Originally: a spot in the eye; a corneal opacity. Later (English regional): a defect in vision (of unknown type). Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1474 Unknown, Bk. Hawking “Þe hauke hath white canwas oþer rede mayle.”

1486 Unknown, Bk. St. Albans “Hawkes haue White maill, Canuas maill or Rede maill. And som call Rede maill Iren mayll. White maill is soone knawe. Canuas maill is betwene white maill and Iron maill. And Iron maill is varri Rede.”

1486 Unknown, Bk. St. Albans “A Goshawke nor a tercell in thare sore aage haue nott thair mayles named bot it is calde their plumage, and after the cote it is calde theyr Maill.”

1530 J. Palsgrave, Lesclarcissement “Mayle of a hauke, greuelure.”

1575 G. Turberville, Bk. Faulconrie “They are ordinarily of foure mayles, eyther blancke, russet, browne, or turtle maylde.”

1614 G. Markham, Cheape & Good Husb. “His eyes round and great, the colour answering the colour of his plume or male.”

1655 I. Walton, Compl. Angler “The wings made of the blackish mail of the Drake.”

1678 J. Ray, Ornithol. “The Mail of a Hawk is the Breast or Plumage of the Breast in reference to its colour: So they say a Hawk changes the mail, or is white-maild, &c.”

1686 R. Blome, Gentlemans Recreation “The little Dun-flye hath his Body made of Dun-Wooll, and his Wings of the Mayle of a Partridge.”

1852 R. F. Burton, Falconry in Valley of Indus “Full breast, covered with regular mail. Note. The ‘mails’ are the breast feathers.”

1967 M. Woodford, Man. Falconry “Mail, the breast feathers of a hawk.”
Content.Answer: mail - The breast feathers of a bird, esp. (in Falconry) those of a hawk when the feathers are fully grown.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mails

1484 W. Caxton, Subtyl Historyes & Fables Esope “And at the bothe his elbowes he hadde wynges ryght brode and grete of fysshes mayles wherwith he swymmed.”
Content.Answer:
mails - In plural. The scales of a fish. Obsolete. rare.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1504 R. Henryson, Garmont Gud Ladeis “Hir kirtill suld be of clene constance, Lasit with lesum lufe, The mailȝeis of continwance, For nevir to remvfe.”

1530 J. Palsgrave, Lesclarcissement “Mayle that receyveth the claspe of a gowne into it, porte.”

1572 J. Cranstoun, Satirical Poems Reformation “My Sleifis wer of to borrow and len glaidlie; My Lais and Mailȝies of trew permanence.”

1588 Unknown, Thomas's Dict. “Orbiculus, the male or rundle thorough which the latchet of the shoe passeth.”

1607 W. N., Barley-breake “And day by day this lace a mayle doth bate.”

1625 Unknown, Brechin Test. “Auchtein hankis of kleispis, keiparis & maillȝeis.”

1647 Unknown, Edinb. Test. “Mailze.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A hole for the passage of a lace, clasp, or other fastening of a garment; an eyelet or ‘eye’. Also figurative. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
many mails make a haubergeon

1597 J. Skene, De Verborum Significatione “The common proverb, manie mailzies makis an haubergion, monie littles makis an meikle.”
Content.Answer:
many mails make a haubergeon - Proverb. many mails make a haubergeon. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1607 E. Topsell, Hist. Foure-footed Beastes “The trunk of the elephant was couered with a maile for defence.”

1609 W. Shakespeare, Troilus & Cressida “To hang, Quite out of fashion like a rusty male.”

1617 F. Moryson, Itinerary “They presently arme al their bodies, and..their very shinbones, and hinder parts, with males of Iron.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A piece of armour composed of mail. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1677 A. Marvell, Poem upon Death Lord Protector “He first put Armes into Religions hand, And tim'rous Conscience unto Courage man'd: The Souldier taught that inward Mail to wear.”

1813 J. N. Brewer, Beauties Eng. & Wales “The antiquaries who have entered the lists, have come cased up in the mail of prejudice.”

1866 B. Taylor, Autumnal Vespers “In stiff December's mail.”
Content.Answer:
mail - figurative. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1713 E. Young, Poem on Last Day “Leviathans but heave their cumbrous Mail.”

1842 Ld. Tennyson, Two Voices “To-day I saw the dragon-fly... From head to tail Came out clear plates of sapphire mail.”

1849 M. Arnold, Forsaken Merman “Where the sea-snakes coil and twine, Dry their mail and bask in the brine.”

1885 R. L. Stevenson, Dynamiter “The mail of a boiled lobster.”

1924 R. Campbell, Flaming Terrapin “The flying Fishes in their silver mail.”
Content.Answer: mail - The protective shell or scales of certain animals.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1727 Unknown, Phillips's New World of Words “Mail, a Speck on the Feathers of Birds.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A speckle on the plumage of a bird. Cf. mailed, adj. 3a. Obsolete. rare.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1731 Unknown, Philos. Trans. “Every Thread of the Warp goes through a small Brass Ring called a Male.”

1831 G. R. Porter, Treat. Silk Manuf. “A modern improvement substitutes for the loops small metallic eyes, through which the warp threads are passed,..these eyes are called mails.”

1894 A. S. Robertson, Provost o' Glendookie “Sandie returned..to work out his destiny amongst harness mails and flying shuttles.”

1927 T. Woodhouse, Artificial Silk: Manuf. & Uses “The threads are drawn through the mails of the healds (often wire ones) and then passed through the dents of a weaving reed.”
Content.Answer: mail - Weaving. A metal eyelet or ring in a loom through which the warp thread passes.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1750 T. R. Blanckley, Naval Expositor “Mails, are made of Iron, and interwoven, not unlike a Chain; they are for rubbing off the loose Hemp which remains on Lines or white Cordage after it is made.”

1794 D. Steel, Elements & Pract. Rigging & Seamanship “Mail, to rub off the loose hemp that remains on white cordage, is a kind of steel chain-work, flat, and fastened upon leather, about nine-inches long and seven-inches broad.”

1867 W. H. Smyth, Sailor's Word-bk. “Mail,..a number of rings interwoven net-wise, and used for rubbing off the loose hemp from white cordage after it is made.”
Content.Answer:
mail - Rope-making. A section of interlinked pieces of metal used for rubbing loose hemp off cordage. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1425 Unknown, Acts Parl. Scotl. “Ande gif it be a man at malis þe hous & birnis it reklesly he sal amende þe scaith efter his power.”

1877 W. Alexander, Notes & Sketches 18th Cent. “A lone woman or two in a ‘mailt-house’.”
Content.Answer:
mail - transitive. To rent, pay rent for.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1447 O. Bokenham, Lives of Saints “What..may þe auayle To forsakyn þe goddys wych leuyn ay, And of her godhed makyn a mayle?”

1449 J. Lydgate, Siege Thebes “For nouther force nor manhode may availle In swiche meschief the valewe of a maylle.”

1469 Unknown, Acts Parl. Scotl. “That thair be na deneris of Frans, mailȝis, cortis..tane in payment in this realme.”

1568 R. Sempill, “Gif my claith felȝie, ȝe pay nocht a melȝie.”

1570 R. Sempill, “Ȝe left him nocht ane Malȝe or Deneir.”

1599 W. Stewart, Bk. Cron. Scotl. “Ȝone tratour till assailȝie In all his tyme wes neuirȝit worth ane melȝie.”

1707 W. Fleetwood, Chronicon Preciosum “Till about 1544, the Silver Money of England consisted of Groats, Half-Groats, Pence, Half-Pence (called, of old, Mails) and Farthings.”

1890 J. Service, Thir Notandums “Gold Pennies and Mailles, Lozenge Lions.”
Content.Answer:
mail - A small coin, normally a half denomination; (spec. in 14th-cent. England) a silver halfpenny. Also figurative.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1449 Unknown, Archiv f. das Studium der Neueren Sprachen “Disdeyn so thik his haburion hath mayled Of my desyre that I may se ryght noghte.”
Content.Answer:
mail - transitive. To make (a piece of armour) out of mail. Obsolete.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1796 R. Southey, Joan of Arc “The martial Maid arose. She mail'd her limbs; The white plumes nodded o'er her helmed head.”

1848 E. Bulwer-Lytton, Harold “I will..ask what Englishmen are there who will aim shaft or spear at this breast, never mailed against England.”

1955 V. Nabokov, Lolita “She would mail her vulnerability in trite brashness and boredom.”
Content.Answer: mail - transitive. To clothe or arm with or as with mail. Also figurative.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1660 J. Evelyn, Diary “Recreating my selfe sometimes at the Maill, & sometymes about the Towne.”

1670 S. Wilson, Lassels's Voy. Italy “Going out of the house, you finde a hansome Mail, and Rare Ponds of water.”

1705 J. Addison, Remarks Italy “A Highway..near as long and as broad as the Mail in St. James's Park.”
Content.Answer:
mail - The game of pall-mall; a place where the game was played. Hence: a public promenade bordered by trees; the Mail: the Mall in St James's Park, London (see mall, n.1).
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1677 W. Nicolson, Gloss. Cumbrian Dial. “Male, to stain.”

1691 J. Ray, Glossarium Northanhymbricum “To Mäle. Decolare.”

1700 W. Kennett, MS Lansdowne 1033 “To male, to discolour, to spot, Northumb.”

1808 J. Jamieson, Etymol. Dict. Sc. Lang. “To Mail, Male, to discolour or stain.”

1818 W. Scott, Heart of Mid-Lothian “A bit rag we hae at hame that was mailed wi' the bluid of a bit skirling wean that was hurt some gate.”
Content.Answer:
mail - transitive. To spot, stain, discolour.
This sense is obsolete
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1827 Unknown, Laws & Regulations Post Office (U.S.) “One or more pieces of paper, mailed as a letter,..shall be charged with quadruple postage.”

1862 Unknown, Morning Star “The Federal Post-office department has issued a notice that any letter mailed with stamps at all soiled or defaced will be treated as unpaid.”

1875 Unknown, Atlantic Monthly “They mail 244,000,000 letters a year.”

1925 A. Loos, Gentlemen prefer Blondes “I told him to write down what he had to say to me, and mail it to me at the Ritz Hotel.”

1948 H. T. Moore, “Lawrence is telling Lady Ottoline that Russell, who has mailed him the synopsis of his lectures..still needs to break away.”

1952 M. McCarthy, Groves of Academe “Maynard Hoar, author of a pamphlet, ‘The Witch Hunt in Our Universities’ (off-printed from the American Scholar and mailed out gratis by the bushel to a legion of ‘prominent educators’).”

1968 M. Richler, “Once more Mervyn mailed off his novel.”

1972 Unknown, Whig-Standard (Kingston, Ont.) “To obtain a pair of Skeelers, consumers must mail in..$9.95 plus provincial tax.”

1992 Unknown, Coin Monthly “The People's Tower at Blackpool ensures that postcards posted in the box at the summit will be mailed as a personalised ‘first day cover’.”
Content.Answer:
mail - transitive. Originally U.S. To send by post, to post. Also with in, off, out.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
mail

1972 A. K. Bhushan, Request for Comments “The files to be mailed are transmitted via the data connection in ascii type.”

1984 C. Townsend, Electronic Mail & Beyond “You will then need to wait a few seconds until the letter is ‘mailed’, and then you will see the prompt again.”

1990 Unknown, Pract. Computing “Cix subscribers are mailed by name, such as jack@cix.”

1996 Unknown, WEBTechniques “You could also use a simple mailto in your form, to mail the unfiltered information directly to your email account.”
Content.Answer: mail - transitive and intransitive. Computing. = email, v.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary
